rev.diff:
Line 250: Line 250:
The book ''Reading National Geographic'' notes how photos are sometimes electronically manipulated.<ref name=iezza>Iezza, Cora McGovern. [http://web.archive.org/web/20060720035500/http://www2.hawaii.edu/~iezza/rng.html "Reading ''Reading National Geographic''"]. 1997. (Via the [[Internet Archive]].){{Self-published inline|date=March 2010}}</ref> In one photo of bare-breasted Polynesian women, the skin color was darkened.<ref name=iezza/> Women with light skin have not appeared topless in the magazine.<ref name=iezza/> The book also documents how NG photographers have encouraged their subjects to change costumes when their clothing was seen as "too drab" for the magazine.<ref name=iezza/> Summarizing an analysis of NG photographs from 1950 to 1986, the authors argue the following themes: "The people of the [[Third World|third]] and [[Fourth World|fourth]] worlds are portrayed as exotic; they are idealized; they are naturalized and taken out of all but a single historical narrative; and they are sexualized. Several of these themes wax and wane in importance through the postwar period, but none is ever absent."<ref>{{cite book | year=1993| url=http://www.amazon.com/Reading-National-Geographic-Catherine-Lutz/dp/0226497240#reader_0226497240| title=Reading National Geographic| page= 89| publisher=University Of Chicago Press| isbn=9780226497242| author=Lutz, Catherine and Jane Collins }}</ref>
The book ''Reading National Geographic'' notes how photos are sometimes electronically manipulated.<ref name=iezza>Iezza, Cora McGovern. [http://web.archive.org/web/20060720035500/http://www2.hawaii.edu/~iezza/rng.html "Reading ''Reading National Geographic''"]. 1997. (Via the [[Internet Archive]].){{Self-published inline|date=March 2010}}</ref> In one photo of bare-breasted Polynesian women, the skin color was darkened.<ref name=iezza/> Women with light skin have not appeared topless in the magazine.<ref name=iezza/> The book also documents how NG photographers have encouraged their subjects to change costumes when their clothing was seen as "too drab" for the magazine.<ref name=iezza/> Summarizing an analysis of NG photographs from 1950 to 1986, the authors argue the following themes: "The people of the [[Third World|third]] and [[Fourth World|fourth]] worlds are portrayed as exotic; they are idealized; they are naturalized and taken out of all but a single historical narrative; and they are sexualized. Several of these themes wax and wane in importance through the postwar period, but none is ever absent."<ref>{{cite book | year=1993| url=http://www.amazon.com/Reading-National-Geographic-Catherine-Lutz/dp/0226497240#reader_0226497240| title=Reading National Geographic| page= 89| publisher=University Of Chicago Press| isbn=9780226497242| author=Lutz, Catherine and Jane Collins }}</ref>
